The trade creates ideal conditions for pathogens to multiply. Of all contributors to the emergence of zoonotic pathogens (such as ecological factors and behavior), â€˜species-jumping' events may be among the most important.
24 They expand the range of viable hosts. Holding different populations of animals together, particularly sick and stressed animals, may result in the spread of new pathogens. A 2003 outbreak of monkeypox in the United States occurred after a shipment of infected African Gambian rats was sold to pet dealers, one of whom housed the rats with prairie dogs.
25, 26 The prairie dogs contracted monkeypox, then were sold as pets, and transmitted the pathogen to 71 people.
